content:
WISER will investigate the impact of weather and 
climate hazards on the Energy Industry – specifically 
focusing on numerical weather prediction, artificial 
intelligence (AI)-based impact modeling, remote 
sensing and vegetation sustainability and system 
and economic modeling. The user-inspired research 
proposed under this IUCRC will provide innovative 
electric grid reliability and resilience solutions to 
renewable energy goals and intensifying 
weather/climate-hazard outage events.

Two NSF IUCRC Centers are characterized by 
research focus areas that are complementary, but 
non-overlapping, to the proposed WISER IUCRC: 1) 
the Center for Wind Energy Science, Technology 
and Research (WindSTAR), and 2) the Wind Hazard 
and Infrastructure Performance Center (WHIP-C). 
WindSTAR has an exclusive focus on wind energy 
but varies considerably from WISER’s focus on 
weather-driven energy research for an optimal 
integration of all renewable energy sources in a smart system. WindSTAR conducts wind energy research 
with an aim to increase the production of this low-carbon energy source through an engineering focus. The 
proposed WISE IUCRC is unique and differs from WindStar in that it is focused on transformative weatherdriven smart energy research through atmospheric and environmental science.
